qas.question: The Archdiocese of Milwaukee says that the correct way to address a cardinal in English is?
What is the proper way to address a cardinal according to the Archdiocese of Milwaukee?

answers.text: by placing the title "Cardinal" (abbreviated Card.) after their personal name and before their surname

qas.question: Why do Oriental Patriarchs sign this way?

answers.text: because they do not belong to the Roman clergy

qas.question: What is not the correct way to address a cardinal according to the Archdiocese of Milwaukee?

plausible_answers.text: by placing the title "Cardinal" (abbreviated Card.) after their personal name and before their surname

qas.question: How do cardinals sign that is not in accordance with tradition?
What style is generally not followed on the websites of the Holy See and episcopal conferences?
How do English Patriarchs typically sign?
Who does not belong to the French clergy?

context: In accordance with tradition, they sign <a2_0><b6_0>by placing the title "Cardinal" (abbreviated Card.) after their personal name and before their surname<b6_0/><a2_0/> as, for instance, "John Card(inal) Doe" or, in Latin, "Ioannes Card(inalis) Cognomen". Some writers, such as James-Charles Noonan, hold that, in the case of cardinals, the form used for signatures should be used also when referring to them in English. Official sources such as the Archdiocese of Milwaukee and Catholic News Service say that the correct form for referring to a cardinal in English is normally as <a0_0><b5_0><b7_0>"<a1_0>Cardinal [First name] [Surname]<b5_0/><a1_0/>"<b7_0/><a0_0/>. This is the rule given also in stylebooks not associated with the Catholic Church. This style is also generally followed on the websites of the Holy See and episcopal conferences. <b9_0>Oriental Patriarchs<b9_0/> who are created Cardinals customarily use "<a3_0><b8_0>Sanctae Ecclesiae Cardinalis<b8_0/><a3_0/>" as their full title, probably <a4_0>because they do not belong to the Roman clergy<a4_0/>.
